content.rendered:
From trippy to minimal to rustic, we have something for whatever ails you this morning with work from Taipei, Gijón, and Vancouver.

Taiwan Designers’ Week 2015 by Ken-Tsai Lee

Celebrated since 2007 Taiwan Designers’ Week just took place earlier this month and brought together over 200 creatives in Taiwan for, you guessed it, a week of design goodness including the “largest annual design exhibition organized by non-governmental sector” and if the identity by Taipei-based Ken-Tsai Lee is any indication, it was a riot. Based on overlaid polygons that create trippy, Saul Bass-esque visuals, the event’s materials are energetic and diverse while the environmental graphics feel like a portal to a design dimension. See full project

Creoquete by atipo

Creoquete is a new shop in Gijón, Spain, specializing in croquettes. This one might remind you of Friday Likes 140’s ba.ro.co as it’s also a three-dot, serif identity. Rest assured that I’m not trying to sound like a broken record, liking the same thing every Friday. (Although it does show consistency on my part). Aside from the minimal, elegant, and earthy design by local firm atipo, what I liked about this project was the play on words which I will try to explain as best as possible to our English readers. The shop’s name, Creoquete, sounds like croquette but it doubles as “Creo que te…” which translates to “I believe that you…” — where the dots in the logo serve as both ellipsis and abstract croquettes. The applications then go on to say things like “Creo que te… Encantan nuestras croquetas” (“I believe that you… Love our croquettes”) or “Creo que te… Estas enganchando” (“I believe that you… Are getting hooked”). It’s charming and playful and the serif-only approach gives it a poetry vibe that gets you right in the mood for croquettes. See full project

Park Distillery by Glasfurd & Walker

Park Distillery is a restaurant and bar in Banff, Canada, providing “campfire-inspired cooking”, which sounds as awesome as the identity by Vancouver-based Glasfurd & Walker looks. The logo and identity uses two typefaces from Letters from Sweden, Ferry and Kumla, that come across as a mix of industrial strength and vernacular signage, which may be tied back to the whole campfire thing. I’m not 100% convinced of the concept but the execution and aesthetic is great, with a perfect mix of colors and materials. And, once again, those enamel cups look far too cool. See full project (Via BP&O)
